title: BSN Sports
shortDescription: As a dev on the front end team that built this sports related eCommerce application, I programmed React components and completed bug-fixes, code reviews, and new feature requests.
description: This sports related eCommerce application provides a platform for thousands of school and community sports teams to custom design and order sporting equipment and uniforms for their teams.
Team managers and coaches can create accounts for their teams, generate custom designs and custom gear and uniforms, and provide links that parents and players can use to order what they need.
This thing is a beast: Over 12,000 commits, over 2,100 Jira tickets, over tens of thousands of lines of code, and nearly two years in development.

title: The Truth Supreme
shortDescription: A full stack social web app with a customizable UI where users can sign up, sign in, post and edit content and vote on content posted by others.
description: The primary purpose behind this project was to demo what I can build.  But it was also something of a fun passion project.

The back end is a Node and SQL REST API, leveraging the Express framework and Sequelize ORM.  The database consists of three tables, each with associations to the other two, utilizing Sequelize's builtin validation, UUIDv4 for primary keys, and custom migrations and seeders.
The front end is a robust React SPA to consume the above REST API, using modern React techniques like functional components and lifecycle hooks.
stack: Functional components with React hooks for state and lifecycle events
Original responsive and mobile-first CSS for a customizable UI with a dark/lite theme and numerous color, accent and background options
Sequelize ORM for validation, CRUD, migrations and seeders
Async await with try catch for async operations
Modular middleware for error handling, route handling, eager loading, async operations, user authorization, and UUID creation for seeder files.
Heroku with a hobby dyno and heroku-postgres for the back end hosting
Netlify for the front end hosting

title: EZ Random User API
shortDescription: A public API that generates random user data to help students and developers test their front ends.
description: This project was built to help the students I mentor.  One of their school projects relies on the [Random User API](https://randomuser.me/) as a third party dependency.  That API is great, but it's gone offline periodically, which created a need for a backup API.  So one day after work, when the API was down, I decided to build my own.

I created a JSON file with an object of arrays containing possible user data.  Additional APIs were used to supply random user images.  I crafted some helper functions to grab random values from the JSON and assemble the info into a new random user object that resembled the schema from the Random User API responses that students were used to using.
Lastly, I deployed to heroku, and before the next, I had a fully functional backup for the Random User API.
stack: Functional JS for retrieving random data for JSON store
Basic markup, responsive stylesheets and ES6 JS for a simple example client to consume the API
GitHub Pages for hosting the front end example

title: Project Warm Ups
shortDescription: A collection of front end coding exercises I designed and built to support the students I used to mentor.
description: The numerous project examples on this app are simple coding exercise that I built to help provide students I mentor with a chance to practice the techniques they'll use in their own projects.
Each consists of a simple front end that provides markup, stylesheets, instructions for completing the challenge and custom tests to check the results of the student's code.

title: EZ Hold 'Em
description: This was just a side project I started for fun.  The app simulates the dealing and game flow for hands of Texas of Hold 'Em.

Using OOP concepts, I created JS classes for the cards, deck, table, dealer and players.  An MVC approach allows for logical control of the app's functionality, data state, and updates to the display.
The next goal is to see if I can add chips for betting and the logic for determining winning hands as well as programming the AI for computer players.

title: React Flickr Gallery
shortDescription: A React SPA for retrieving photos from the Flickr API.
description: The students I mentor have to build a project like this.  So I built this one myself to better support the students.
Create React App was used to start this project.  I created a Flickr account to acquire a key to query their API, which is defined in environment variables for security.

App uses only functional components with hooks for managing state and lifecycle events.  All state is mainly managed in container components, with data passed down to stateless presentational components.  The application listens for changes to the URL and then updates, searches and displays results as needed. No search results and undefined routes are handled gracefully.
stack: Functional components and hooks for state and lifecycle events
Fetch, async/await and try catch blocks for reliably retrieving API data
Custom environment variables for securely using my Flickr private key

title: Code Crossword
shortDescription: A front end crossword app to provide students with a fun way to practice their coding vocabulary.
description: I created this project mainly to see if I could.  I used a basic MVC/OOP approach and created one file to hold an object of puzzle objects containing all the clues and answers, one file to handle the main puzzle functionality, one file to handle updating the UI, and one main script file to wire it all up and listen for user events.

At some point I may refactor this one to improve the code and maybe create a crossword generator feature that lets users enter words and clues into a form in order to produce their own custom crosswords that they could share with friends.
stack: Responsive CSS using Flexbox, CSS variables and custom UI components

title: The E Ching
